<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 238, 176, 248]]<|/det|> NUMBER <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 290]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 290]]<|/det|> **0625/52** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test **October/November 2018** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 322, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 352]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 584, 372]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 393, 388, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 781, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 327, 445]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 616, 460]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 505, 474]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 904, 542]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and about 15 minutes on question 4. Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 545, 767, 556]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 571, 605, 582]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 757, 597]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 647, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 854, 836, 863]]<|/det|> This syllabus is approved for use in England, Wales and Northern Ireland as a Cambridge International Level 1/Level 2 Certificate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 877, 664, 888]]<|/det|> This document consists of 12 printed pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 698, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the spring constant \(k\) of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 576, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 135, 755, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 415, 532, 433]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 446, 146, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 917, 479]]<|/det|>
The metre rule is fixed in position close to the spring. **Do not change the position of the metre rule.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 494, 180, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 917, 527]]<|/det|>
Use the set-square provided to take readings from the metre rule in order to determine the length \(l_0\) of the coiled part of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 540, 917, 558]]<|/det|>
Record of readings taken ....................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 570, 918, 588]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 600, 180, 619]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 600, 918, 619]]<|/det|>
Record in Table 1.1 the value of the length of the spring \(l_0\) when the load \(L\) is 0.00N.  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 632, 180, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 632, 918, 666]]<|/det|>
• Place a load of 0.20N on the spring. Record in Table 1.1 the new length \(l\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 679, 918, 712]]<|/det|>
• Use the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\) to calculate the extension \(e\) of the spring. Record the value of \(e\) in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 725, 918, 758]]<|/det|>
• Repeat the procedure using loads of 0.40N, 0.60N, 0.80N and 1.00N. Record all the readings and results in the table.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 58, 539, 73]]<|/det|> ## 3 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[317, 103, 680, 279]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 75, 539, 90]]<|/det|> Table 1.1
L/Nl/mme/mm
0.000
0.20
0.40
0.60
0.80
1.00
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 281, 920, 298]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 313, 148, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 313, 576, 330]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(L / N\) (y-axis) against \(e / \text{mm}\) (x-axis). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[208, 342, 789, 755]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 755, 920, 772]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 785, 146, 804]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 918, 818]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 908, 918, 925]]<|/det|>
G = .................................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 652, 90]]<|/det|>
The gradient \(G\) is numerically equal to the spring constant \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 861, 120]]<|/det|>
Write down a value for \(k\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 134, 890, 151]]<|/det|>
<form>k = .................................................... N/mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 165, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 598, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the power of lamps.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 555, 120]]<|/det|>
The circuit shown in Fig. 2.1 has been set up for you.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 132, 608, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 280, 533, 298]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 313, 146, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 313, 180, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 313, 284, 330]]<|/det|>
Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 344, 918, 377]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{T}}\) across the lamps and the current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\) in the circuit. Switch off.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 390, 915, 408]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{T}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (2)\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 433, 915, 451]]<|/det|>
\[I_{\mathrm{T}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots  \quad (2)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 185, 501]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 483, 905, 500]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P_{\mathrm{T}}\) produced by the lamp filaments, using the equation \(P_{\mathrm{T}} = V_{\mathrm{T}}I_{\mathrm{T}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 575, 918, 592]]<|/det|>
<form>P_{\mathrm{T}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad [1]</FORM>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 791, 90]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter. Reconnect the voltmeter across lamp X. Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 180, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{X}}\) across lamp X and the current \(I_{\mathrm{X}}\) in the circuit. Switch off.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 149, 917, 168]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{X}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 180, 917, 199]]<|/det|>
\[I_{\mathrm{X}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots  \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 227, 181, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 227, 892, 244]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P_{\mathrm{X}}\) produced by the lamp filament using the equation \(P_{\mathrm{X}} = V_{\mathrm{X}}I_{\mathrm{X}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 319, 917, 337]]<|/det|>
\[P_{\mathrm{X}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 350, 146, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 350, 789, 368]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter. Reconnect the voltmeter across lamp Y. Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 382, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 382, 918, 415]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{Y}}\) across lamp Y and the current \(I_{\mathrm{Y}}\) in the circuit. Switch off.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 428, 915, 446]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{Y}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 459, 917, 477]]<|/det|>
\[I_{\mathrm{Y}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots  \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 185, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 892, 523]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P_{\mathrm{Y}}\) produced by the lamp filament using the equation \(P_{\mathrm{Y}} = V_{\mathrm{Y}}I_{\mathrm{Y}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 583, 917, 600]]<|/det|>
\[P_{\mathrm{Y}} = \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 613, 148, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 613, 918, 645]]<|/det|>
State and explain briefly whether your two values for power, \(P_{\mathrm{X}}\) and \(P_{\mathrm{Y}}\) are the same within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 660, 917, 677]]<|/det|>
statement ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 692, 917, 708]]<|/det|>
explanation ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 739, 918, 757]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 660, 90]]<|/det|>
Draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit rearranged so that:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 484, 120]]<|/det|>
• the lamps are connected in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 648, 151]]<|/det|>
• the ammeter will measure the total current in the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 630, 182]]<|/det|>
• the voltmeter will measure the p.d. across the lamps.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 479, 213]]<|/det|>
You are **not** asked to set up this circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 492, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 523, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 912, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the refractive index \(n\) of the material of a transparent block.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 103, 819, 617]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 630, 532, 647]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 660, 146, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 660, 917, 692]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. Refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 707, 917, 740]]<|/det|>
• Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 755, 574, 771]]<|/det|>
• Draw and label the outline of the block ABCD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 917, 816]]<|/det|>
• Remove the block and draw the normal NL at the centre of side AB. Continue the normal so that it passes through side CD of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 832, 525, 848]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{F}\) where NL crosses AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 863, 529, 878]]<|/det|>
• Label the point G where NL crosses CD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 876, 918, 894]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 75, 777, 93]]<|/det|>
• Draw the line EF at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 106, 472, 123]]<|/det|>
• Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 136, 880, 155]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line EF at a suitable distance apart for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 168, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
• Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 230, 918, 261]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3, \mathsf{P}_4,\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2,\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 275, 525, 293]]<|/det|>
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1, \mathsf{P}_2, \mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 306, 457, 323]]<|/det|>
• Remove the block and the pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 338, 918, 370]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets the normal NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 384, 638, 402]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{J}\) where the line meets the normal NL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 415, 737, 433]]<|/det|>
• Label the point \(\mathbf{H}\) where the line meets side \(\mathbf{CD}\). Draw the line \(\mathbf{FH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 432, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 462, 146, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 180, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 462, 586, 479]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line FH.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 492, 918, 510]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ...........................................................................[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 180, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 586, 540]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line HJ.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 554, 918, 571]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ...........................................................................[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 591, 180, 610]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 591, 660, 610]]<|/det|>
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) using the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 653, 918, 670]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ...........................................................................[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 685, 149, 702]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 685, 685, 702]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in (b) using the angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 715, 180, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 715, 555, 733]]<|/det|>
Repeat the measurements in (c) for \(i = 40^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 747, 918, 764]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 778, 918, 795]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ............................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 795, 920, 813]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 825, 180, 844]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 825, 660, 844]]<|/det|>
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) using the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 887, 918, 905]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ...........................................................................[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A student carries out this experiment with care and expects the two values of refractive index \(n\) obtained in this experiment to be equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 918, 151]]<|/det|>
State two difficulties with this type of experiment that could account for any difference in the two values of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 917, 180]]<|/det|>
1. ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 227, 917, 242]]<|/det|>
2. ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 275, 918, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 305, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 381, 815, 397]]<|/det|>
<pre>Tie your ray-trace sheet into this Question Booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating whether the type of container affects the time taken for water to be heated from room temperature to boiling point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 420, 136]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 350, 275]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ copper can  250 cm³ aluminium can  250 cm³ glass beaker   Bunsen burner   measuring cylinder   thermometer   tripod and gauze   stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 290, 712, 306]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally used in the school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 321, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the type of container affects the time taken for water to be heated from room temperature to boiling point. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 383, 218, 399]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 415, 617, 431]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 446, 531, 462]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 477, 918, 509]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 524, 737, 540]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.
